name: Kristen Shinohara
bio: Kristen was a PhD student advised by Jake Wobbrock and Wanda Pratt. She worked with Andy multiple times as a teaching assistant, and later on nationwide survey of higher education instruction on accessibility. She graduated in 2017 and joined the faculty at Rochester Institute of Technology.

name: Annie Yan
bio: Annie worked with Andy on predicting dropout in a coding tutorial.

name: Ada Kim
bio: Ada worked with Andy on a pedagogical analysis of coding tutorials.

name: Saba Kawas
bio: Saba is a PhD student in the Information School. She worked with Andy on a nationwide survey of higher education instruction on accessibility

name: Benjamin Xie
bio: Benji is a PhD student in the College of Education interested in learning analytics for computing education. Before joining UW, he studied App Inventor and MOOCs with Hal Abelson at MIT.

name: Greg Nelson
bio: Greg is a PhD student in Computer Science and Engineering at the University of Washington. He studies and conducts research in human computer interaction and computing education.

name: Kyle Thayer
bio: Kyle is a PhD student in Computer Science and Engineering, also working with Katharina Reinecke. He studies diversity and learning technologies in computing education.

name: Roshanak Zilouichian
bio: Roshanak was a postdoc in my lab working on collaboration, consensus, information visualization, and creativity support tools. She received her Ph.D. from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and investigated social aspects of online coding tutorials while at UW.

name: Amanda Swearngin
bio: Amanda is interested in Software Engineering, HCI, and making software easier to learn, use, and make. She is investigating how web sites change and how we can reveal and explain those changes to end users.

name: Michael J. Lee
bio: Michael Lee, now faculty at New Jersey Institute of Technology, was a PhD student in the Information School at the University of Washington, advised by Andrew Ko. His research interests include the social aspects of software development and maintenance, and computer programming education. He has published articles for multi-modal programming environments for children, receiving a best paper award at the ACM Conference on Creativity & Cognition (C&C). He received his Masters degree in 2007 from the School of Information at UC Berkeley, advised by Kimiko Ryokai and Robert Glushko. He received his Bachelors of Science with Distinction in 2005 from the Cognitive Science Department at UC San Diego, advised by David Kirsh and Edwin Hutchins. He is now an Assistant Professor at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Information Systems.

name: Paul Luo Li
bio: Paul Luo Li, now a Senior Data Scientist at Microsoft, was a Ph.D. student in the Information School at the University of Washington, advised by Andrew Ko. His research area is Software Engineering Processes. His research interests include user experiences in software engineering activities. He has publications on reliability engineering and metrics in conferences like ICSE and ISSRE. He has a Masters in Software Engineering from Carnegie Mellon University, and a B.S. in Statistics with a minor in Computer Science from the University of Virginia.

name: Brian Burg
bio: Brian Burg, now a Senior Software Engineer at Apple, was a Ph.D. student in the CSE Department at the University of Washington, advised by Andrew Ko. His research areas include improving developer productivity, quantifying and furthering application and runtime performance, and understanding languages and software at scale. Brian received his Bachelor of Science with Honors in Computer Science from Purdue University. He is now a Senior Software Engineer at Apple.

name: Dastyni Loksa
bio: Dastyni is a Ph.D. student in the the Information School. His research focuses on problem solving in programming, with a particular focus on self-regulated learning, spanning the fields of HCI and computing education. Dastyni completed his bachelors in Informatics at the University of California, Irvine.

name: Zakariya Dehlawi
bio: Zak is a Ph.D. student in the the Information School, co-advised by Andrew Ko and Barbara Endicott-Popovsky. He received his Master of Science in Security Informatics from Johns Hopkins in 2011 and bachelor degrees in Computer Engineering and Political Science from the University of Washington in 2009. His research focuses on security practices in software teams and organizations and he serves as a Senior Security Engineer at Security Innovation, Inc.

name: Parmit K. Chilana
bio: Parmit K. Chilana, now faculty at Simon Fraser University, was a PhD student at the Information School. Her research interests span different aspects of software development, usability, and software support. In recent projects, she has looked at how users express unwanted software behaviors and how support professionals and developers diagnose and respond to user-reported software issues in open source and commercial software development contexts. She is currently exploring the design of contextual-help tools for web applications which leverage crowdsourced solutions from users. Parmit has also collaborated on various projects within UW Medicine and biomedical and health informatics related to improving design of software used for scientific research. Parmit received her MS in Library and Information Science from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and BSc in Computing Science from Simon Fraser University, Canada. She was a recipient of Canada's SSHRC doctoral fellowship in 2009 and a Facebook PhD fellowship in 2010.
